questions.question:
Question 1: A woman presents with fever with chills and a productive cough. Chest X-ray is suggestive of 
lobar pneumonia. She had undergone splenectomy 2 years back. Sputum culture on blood 
agar shows the following. What is the causative agent?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario of bacterial pneumonia in a splenectomised individual along with the image 
showing satellitism on blood agar points towards an infection due to Hemophilus influenzae. Pneumonia can occur as a part of overwhelming post-splenectomy infection (OPSI). This is a fatal 
post-splenectomy complication occuring due to infections with encapsulated organisms such as S. 
pneumoniae, H. influenzae, and N. meningitidis. It can be prevented by vaccinating against these 
organisms within 2 weeks of undergoing splenectomy. Satellitism is seen when S. aureus is streaked across a plate of blood agar on which H. influenzae 
has been inoculated. After overnight incubation, the colonies of H. influenzae will be large and 
well developed alongside the streak of Staphylococcus and smaller when they are farther away 
from the streak. This is due to the release of factor V by lysis of RBCs mediated by S. aureus. 
Factor V is required for the growth of H. influenzae. The given image shows satellitism on blood agar 254 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 2: A patient presented with fever, seizures, and altered sensorium. Gram stain of the CSF is 
given below. Satellitism was seen on blood agar. Which of the following statements is false 
about this disease? 249 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: This is the most serious disease produced by this organism.
options.b: The disease is more common in young adults.
options.c: The bacilli reach the meninges from the nasopharynx through the bloodstream.
options.d: Cefotaxime is the drug of choice

questions.explanation:
The given scenario and the image showing gram-negative coccobacilli in the CSF are suggestive of 
hemophilus meningitis caused by H.influenzae. Hemophilus meningitis is more common in 
children between 3 months and 3 years of age and not common in young adults. Other options: Option A: Meningitis is the most serious disease caused by H. influenzae. The case fatality rate is 
90% if untreated. Option C: H. influenze is transmitted via respiratory droplets. Thus, it is introduced into the 
nasopharynx of the contacts of an infected individual. It has to enter the bloodstream to reach the 
meninges. Option D: Cefotaxime or ceftazidime are the drugs of choice for the treatment of hemophilus 
meningitis.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following is not caused by non-typable H. influenzae?
questions.explanation:
Meningitis is caused by typable H. influenzae. Non-typable H. influenzae cause: • Otitis media • Sinusitis • Puerperal sepsis • Exacerbations of COPD. 255 
Sold by @itachibot H. influenzae is typed into 6 serotypes (a to f) based on the capsular polysaccharide. 
Serotype b (Hib) is the most virulent and accounts for most of the invasive infections. The differences between type b strains and non-typable strains of H. influenzae are given in the

questions.question:
Question 5: A 7-year-old girl presents to the emergency with acute stridor. The mother gives a history of 
fever, drooling, and breathing difficulty since that morning. An X-ray of her neck appears as 
given below. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical vignette and 'thumb sign' on the X-ray are suggestive of acute epiglottitis caused 
by Hemophilus influenzae. It is an acute inflammation of the epiglottis causing obstructive laryngitis and presents with high 
fever, severe sore throat, tachycardia, systemic toxicity, and drooling as patients are unable to 
swallow. The patient characteristically leans forward while sitting for ease of breathing. The diagnosis often is made on clinical grounds. On direct fiberoptic laryngoscopy, the typical 
edematous cherry-red epiglottis is visualized. Neck radiographs reveal an enlarged edematous 
epiglottis (Thumb sign). The below image shows the Thumb sign. In some countries, widespread vaccination against Hib has drastically decreased acute epiglottitis 
cases in children by over 90%. However, the incidence in adults has remained largely unchanged 
since the Hib vaccine was introduced. Despite vaccination efforts, many pediatric cases of 
epiglottitis today are still caused by Hib due to either lack of vaccination or vaccine 
ineffectiveness. In adults and increasingly in children, other bacterial pathogens, particularly 
group A Streptococcus, have been linked to cases of epiglottitis. Treatment includes airway management followed by administration of antibiotics like 
ampicillin/sulbactam, cefotaxime, or ceftriaxone.

questions.question:
Question 6: Pneumonia due to a gram-negative pleomorphic bacillus growing on chocolate agar which is 
catalase and oxidase-positive is:
questions.explanation:
Pneumonia due to a gram-negative pleomorphic bacillus growing on chocolate agar which is 
catalase and oxidase-positive is most likely Haemophilus influenza. Haemophilus pneumonia typically occurs in infants and is accompanied by empyema and 
sometimes meningitis as well. In older children and adults, the picture is of lobar 
pneumonia. Sputum is collected for the detection and isolation of Hemophilus. As the bacillus is 
very sensitive to low temperatures, specimens should never be refrigerated before inoculation. 
H.infiuenzae is a Gram-negative, non-motile, non-sporing bacillus, exhibiting considerable 257 
Sold by @itachibot pleomorphism. In sputum, it usually occurs as clusters of coccobacillary forms. The bacillus has fastidious growth requirements. The accessory growth factors, named X and V, 
present in the blood are essential for growth. Catalase and oxidase reactions are positive. Nitrates are reduced to nitrites. Biotyping has been done on the 
basis of indole production. Cultures may be preserved for about a month on chocolate agar slopes. Chocolate agar is made by 
heating blood agar to 80-90°C for 15-20 minutes. This causes the release of V factor from within 
the erythrocytes. Treatment- Amoxycillin-clavulanate or clarithromycin is more effective in treating respiratory 
infections by Haemophilus influenzae.

questions.question:
Question 7: A middle-aged man who is a known case of diabetes and chronic bronchitis presents to the 
OPD with low-grade fever and productive cough for 5 days. Which of the following is not a 251 
Sold by @itachibot virulence factor of the likely causative organism?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario describes an acute exacerbation of COPD characterized by low-grade 
fever, increased cough, sputum production, and shortness of breath. The most common cause of 
these are non-typable H. influenzae which lack a capsule and so capsular antigen cannot be a 
virulence factor. All H. influenzae have the following virulence factors: • Outer membrane proteins (OMP) • Lipooligosaccharide(LOS) • Pili In addition to the above factors, H. influenzae type b also has its capsular polysaccharide as a

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following bacteria does not belong to the HACEK group?
questions.explanation:
258 
Sold by @itachibot Escherichia coli does not belong to the HACEK group. The acronym HACEK refers to a group of fastidious slow-growing bacteria, normally residing in 
the mouth. These can sometimes cause severe infections, particularly culture-negative subacute 
bacterial endocarditis. The group includes: • Haemophilus species (H. parainfluenzae, H. aphrophilus, H. paraphrophilus) • Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans (previously called as Actinobacillus) • Cardiobacterium hominis • Eikenella corrodens • Kingella kingae

questions.question:
Question 9: A 26-year-old man presented with painful, bleeding genital ulcers. On examination, tender 
inguinal lymphadenopathy is present. Scraping from the ulcer base was taken and the 
microscopic appearance of the Gram-stained smear is shown below. What is the causative 
organism?
questions.explanation:
The image shows the' school of fish' or 'railroad track' appearance of Haemophilus ducreyi. This 
appearance is seen when the bacilli are arranged in small groups, whorls or in chains. The given 
case scenario is suggestive of chancroid. Chancroid is characterized by non-indurated, tender, irregular ulcers that may bleed on touch. 
The neighbouring lymph nodes are enlarged, painful, and tender. Other options: Option B - Treponema pallidum causes syphilis, characterised by chancre - a single painless ulcer 
with a clean base and a firm raised border, with painless lymphadenopathy. Persistent or multiple 
chancres may be seen in HIV-infected or other immunodeficient patients. Options C and D - Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1, L2 and L3 cause lymphogranuloma 
venereum, characterised by shallow, painless ulcers that progress to painful lymphadenopathy.

questions.question: Question 10: The following are true about chancroid:
questions.explanation:
Chancroid is a painful genital ulcer caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, which is a gram-negative 
coccobacillus. Microscopic appearance of H. ducreyi is called the school of fish appearance or 
railroad appearance. Chancroid ulcers have a soft base that bleeds easily to touch. They also cause 
painful lymphadenopathy. The image below shows the 'school-of-fish' appearance characteristic of H. ducreyi. 259 
Sold by @itachibot Note: Groove sign is a characteristic sign seen in lymphogranuloma venereum. It refers to the 
depression created by the inguinal ligament as it passes between the groups of inflamed inguinal 
lymph nodes.

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following is not involved in urethritis?
questions.explanation:
Haemophilus ducreyi does not cause urethritis. It causes chancroid (soft chancre), which presents 
as a genital ulcer. Urethritis is classified into two types: • Gonococcal urethritis - caused by Neisseria gonorrhoea. • Non-gonococcal urethritis - caused by: • Chlamydia trachomatis (most common) • Ureaplasma urealyticum • Adenovirus • Haemophilus vaginalis • Mycoplasma genitalium • Tricomonas vaginalis (rare) • Herpes simplex virus (rare)

questions.question:
Question 12: A 5-year-old girl presents with conjunctivitis, fever, and hemorrhagic skin lesions. There's a 
history of travel to Brazil. Which of the following etiological agents would you suspect in this 
case?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of Brazilian purpuric fever (BPF) caused by Haemophilus 
aegypticus (Koch-Weeks bacillus). 260 
Sold by @itachibot Recent DNA studies have shown that the bacillus is identical to non-capsulated H.influenzae 
and it is now named H.influenzae biotype aegypticus. It is worldwide in distribution and causes: • A highly contagious form of conjunctivitis ('pink eye') which is especially common in the tropics 
and subtropics and may lead to epidemics. It responds to local sulphonamide or gentamicin 
administration. • Brazilian purpuric fever characterized by fever, purpura, and conjunctivitis which proceeds to 
fulminant septicemia in infants and children. It has a high fatality rate. 261 
Sold by @itachibot Miscellaneous Bacteria - Yersinia, Brucella, Bartonella, Legionella
